problem.tex: Let $g$ be an entire function and define $f(z)$ by \[f(z):=\frac{g(z)}{\sin(-iz^2)}.\] Here, we add the assumption that $g(z)\neq0$ for any zero of $\sin(-iz^2)$, and we define $f$ only where $\sin(-iz^2)\neq0$. (a) What are the zeros of $\sin(-iz^2)$? Sketch their locations in $\mathbb{C}$. (b) For $n\in\mathbb{N}$, let $a=\sqrt{2n\pi}$ lie on the positive real axis. Determine the radius of convergence of the power series for $f$ expanded about $a$.

solution.tex: a) Recall $\sin(z)=\frac{1}{2i}(e^{iz}-e^{-iz})$, this is the most computationally-convenient definition of complex $\sin$. This vanishes precisely when $e^{iz}=e^{-iz}$, which is equivalent to $e^{2iz}=1$. If $z=x+iy$ then this is also \[e^{-2y}e^{2ix}=1.\] Taking modulus implies $e^{-2y}=1$, so this is only satisfied when $y=0$. Assume $y=0$, we are solving $e^{2ix}=1$. We know that $e^0=1$ and we know $e^z$ is $2\pi i$-periodic in $z$, so this is satisfied precisely when $x=\pi k$ for some integer $k$. Thus $\sin(z)=0$ if and only if $z=\pi k$ for some integer $k$. Substituting $w=-iz^2$ and using our knowledge that $\sin(w)=0$ if and only if $w=2\pi k$ gives that $\sin(-iz^2)=0$ if and only if $-iz^2=2\pi k$, or $z=\pm\sqrt{2\pi ik}$ for $k\in\mathbb{Z}$. b) The radius of convergence will be the largest it can be without surpassing a pole. The closest pole to $a$ is $0$, so the radius of convergence is $a$ itself.
